*G.L. c. 208, \u0000\u0000\u0000\u0000\u.proposition: These facts constitute a material and substantial change in circumstances since the original custody judgment, requiring judicial review under *G.L. c. 208, �������������������������������������������������������������������*, and Massachusetts caselaw.

*G.L. c. 209C, \u0000\u0000\u0000\u0000\.proposition: Under *G.L. c. 208, ���������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������, ����������������������������������������������������������������������� (�applicable to divorced parents�) and *G.L. c. 209C, ������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������� (�for parents of children born out of wedlock, if applicable�), a court may modify an existing custody order upon proof of a **material change in circumstances** and when such modification serves the **best interests of the child**.

*Scholl v. Scholl*, 380 Mass. 232 (1980).proposition: In *Scholl v. Scholl*, 380 Mass. 232 (1980), the Supreme Judicial Court held that modification is proper when changed conditions affect the child’s welfare.
*Scholl v. Scholl*, 380 Mass. 232 (1980).support_reasoning: The provided opinion text is not Scholl v. Scholl at all; it is Commonwealth v. Sellon, a criminal case concerning ineffective assistance of counsel, evidentiary rulings, and jury instructions in a manslaughter prosecution. It does not involve domestic relations, child custody, or modification standards, nor does it address whether modification is proper when changed conditions affect a child’s welfare. Therefore, this case cannot support the family-law modification proposition attributed to Scholl v. Scholl.
*Scholl v. Scholl*, 380 Mass. 232 (1980).relevant_excerpt: “Convicted of manslaughter on an indictment charging murder in the first degree, the defendant William A. Sellon appeals. … Sellon’s principal argument is that he was denied the effective assistance of counsel at trial.”

*Cooper v. Cooper*, 43 Mass. App. Ct. 51.proposition: In *Cooper v. Cooper*, 43 Mass. App. Ct. 51 (1997), the Appeals Court reaffirmed that the child’s best interest is paramount, especially when a parent’s relocation significantly impacts the custodial arrangement.
*Cooper v. Cooper*, 43 Mass. App. Ct. 51.support_reasoning: The opinion in Cooper v. Cooper is an alimony contempt and modification/separation-agreement case. It deals with ability to pay, consideration of potential income, assets, and a second spouse’s income, and the constraining effect of a surviving separation agreement. It does not address custody, relocation, or best-interests-of-the-child standards at all. Therefore it cannot be used as authority for the proposition that the Appeals Court reaffirmed that the child’s best interest is paramount in relocation affecting custody.
*Cooper v. Cooper*, 43 Mass. App. Ct. 51.relevant_excerpt: On June 11, 1987, the parties, both represented by counsel, executed a separation agreement which made comprehensive provisions for alimony, child support and property division. The agreement was to “survive as an independent agreement” after their divorce. The agreement included a provision that permitted Phillip the “opportunity to accept employment which is more consistent with his career goals than his present position.” ... The Probate Court judge’s finding was reasonable. She read the language of their 1989 agreement to preclude future reduction based upon change in Phillip’s employment.

*Smith v. McDonald*, 458 Mass. 540 (2010.proposition: *Smith v. McDonald*, 458 Mass. 540 (2010) recognized relocation and burdensome travel as factors sufficient to warrant modification of parenting time schedules.
*Smith v. McDonald*, 458 Mass. 540 (2010.support_reasoning: The concurring opinion makes clear that the relocation itself was not a basis to alter the mother’s custodial status and rejects application of removal principles; it instructs that the mother’s move must be treated as a given and only used to craft an appropriate long‑distance visitation order. The case does not hold that relocation and burdensome travel, by themselves, are factors sufficient to warrant modification of parenting time; instead, it limits the court’s authority to disturb the relocating custodial parent’s decision. Thus, the opinion does not support the proposition as framed.
*Smith v. McDonald*, 458 Mass. 540 (2010.relevant_excerpt: “After paternity was established, the judge was obligated to take as a given that the mother and the child resided 400 miles apart from, and in another State than, the father, and to fashion custody and visitation orders pursuant to the three factors set out in G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a), again respecting and not disturbing the mother’s decision to relocate. … Seen in light of the mother’s legitimate New York residence … the distance separating the parties had relevance only as a factor in devising a reasonable long-distance visitation order….”

*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: *Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006), the SJC emphasized that the **best interests of the child** remain the controlling consideration in all custody matters.
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: The opinion expressly states that under G. L. c. 208, § 30, removal may be ordered only if it is in the children’s best interests and repeatedly frames the entire removal/custody analysis in terms of the children’s best interests as the governing standard. The SJC both reaffirms prior precedents and applies the best-interests test as the controlling consideration in resolving the relocation dispute, so the case accurately supports the proposition that best interests remain the controlling consideration in custody matters involving removal.
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 208, § 30, provides that … [a minor child] shall not … be removed out of this Commonwealth … without the consent of both parents, unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders. ‘The words “upon cause shown” mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child.’ … ‘[T]he best interests of the child standard is one grounded in the particular needs and circumstances of the individual child in question.’ … [W]e review her determination of the best interests of the children only for an abuse of discretion.”

*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: *Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001), confirmed that a “substantial change in distance” between homes and resultant educational or emotional disruption supports modification.
*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The case does not state that a substantial change in distance between homes and resulting educational or emotional disruption supports modification of custody. To the contrary, the court holds that relocation (and the associated change in the child’s school or routines) cannot itself constitute the material and substantial change required to modify a prior custody judgment. The opinion reverses a custody change that was based essentially on the relocation and emphasizes that such a move is distinct from, and cannot by itself justify, a modification under G.L. c. 208, § 28.
*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: "Our decision today, that a request for modification of custody is distinct from a request to relocate and must be based on a material and substantial change in circumstances other than the move, is consistent with these decisions and with G. L. c. 208, § 28... The custody claim must be considered in light of established principles governing custody determinations."

*Chicos v. Chicos*, 71 Mass. App. Ct. 56.proposition: *Chicos v. Chicos*, 71 Mass. App. Ct. 568 (2008), further illustrated that modifications reducing disruption to the child’s education and stability serve their best interests.
*Chicos v. Chicos*, 71 Mass. App. Ct. 56.support_reasoning: The opinion in Chicos v. Chicos is a criminal case about involuntary manslaughter, public trial rights, sequestration of a witness, and sentencing (including consideration of remorse and an illegal firearm sentence). It does not involve child custody, parenting plans, educational disruption, or modifications based on a child’s educational stability. Therefore it does not support the proposition that modifications reducing disruption to a child’s education and stability serve the child’s best interests; the subject matter is entirely different.
*Chicos v. Chicos*, 71 Mass. App. Ct. 56.relevant_excerpt: The defendant appeals from jury convictions of involuntary manslaughter, found as a lesser included offense of the original charge of murder in the first degree, and of illegal possession of a firearm. He claims that the motion judge violated his right to a public trial by excluding his girlfriend, Gwynne Doyle, from the hearing on his motion to suppress "all statements made by him to the police." ... Finally, he claims that the sentence imposed on the firearm offense is illegal and must be vacated. We affirm as to the conviction and sentence for involuntary manslaughter, but remand for resentencing on the firearm offense.

*Pizzino v. Miller*, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 8.proposition: *Pizzino v. Miller*, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865 (2006), educational continuity and adequate rest are valid, independent grounds for adjusting parenting schedules under §��������������������������������������������������������������������������
*Pizzino v. Miller*, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 8.support_reasoning: The opinion is a removal case under G.L. c. 208, § 30, applying the Yannas “real advantage/best interests” framework. While the court does mention schooling quality, transition issues, and the children’s difficulties with change as factors in the best‑interests analysis, it does not treat “educational continuity” or “adequate rest” as independent, freestanding grounds for adjusting parenting schedules under any particular statute. The holding concerns how to weigh a custodial parent’s remarriage and the real‑advantage test in a relocation context, not schedule adjustments based on schooling or rest as standalone legal bases.
*Pizzino v. Miller*, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 8.relevant_excerpt: “In the present case, the judge found, on conflicting evidence, that the proposed move to South Carolina was not in the children’s best interests because of considerations of schooling, housing, transition issues, financial security and separation from family, including their father. Ordinarily we would defer to such findings.… Because the judge found, perhaps erroneously, that the proposed move offered no real advantage to the mother, he obviously gave no weight to any real advantage to her in his calculus regarding the children’s best interests.”

*Rosen v. Rosen*, 90 Mass. App. Ct. 677.proposition: *Rosen v. Rosen*, 90 Mass. App. Ct. 677 (2016), reaffirmed that practical difficulties caused by a parent’s relocation can justify eliminating midweek overnights.
*Rosen v. Rosen*, 90 Mass. App. Ct. 677.support_reasoning: The opinion is entirely about equitable credits against child support arrears and related contempt/arrearage/college-expense issues. It does not discuss parental relocation, visitation schedules, or midweek overnights. Nothing in the holding or reasoning concerns modifying parenting time because of practical relocation difficulties, so the proposition misattributes a principle that this case does not address.
*Rosen v. Rosen*, 90 Mass. App. Ct. 677.relevant_excerpt: “Today we reach the question left open in T.M. v. L.H., 50 Mass. App. Ct. 856, 861 (2001), namely, whether ‘a judge, in compelling circumstances of an equitable nature, and without contravening G. L. c. 119A, § 13(a), may apply a credit in calculating child support arrearages to reflect payments made in a manner other than as directed by the original [child support] order.’ We conclude that ... a judge may — in certain very limited circumstances — grant and apply such an equitable credit to offset a child support arrearage...”

*G.L. c. 208, \u0000\u0000\u0000\u0000\u.proposition: *G.L. c. 208, ��������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������* mandates that custody decisions promote the child’s welfare and stability, with due regard to schooling, developmental needs, and the parties’ ability to cooperate.

Additional authorities supporting modification include *G.L. c. 208, ���������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������, permitting orders adjusted to serve the child's best interests, and *Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003), underscoring the court’s discretion to respond when a prior arrangement no longer serves the child.

*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: Additional authorities supporting modification include *G.L. c. 208, § 28A*, permitting orders adjusted to serve the child's best interests, and *Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003), underscoring the court’s discretion to respond when a prior arrangement no longer serves the child.
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: The proposition characterizes Custody of Kali as authority about a court’s discretion to modify a prior custody arrangement when it no longer serves the child. This opinion, however, treats the case as an initial custody determination under G.L. c. 209C, § 10(a), explicitly declining to apply or discuss the modification standard and focusing instead on the best‑interests analysis and stability of existing arrangements. It therefore does not support a legal proposition about standards for or discretion in post‑judgment modification of custody orders.
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: “We also decline to consider the father’s claim that the probate judge should have applied the ‘substantial change in the circumstances’ standard applicable to modification actions brought under G. L. c. 209C, § 20, rather than the ‘best interests of the child’ standard applicable to custody determinations under G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a). … It is clear from the record that the case in the Probate Court was tried under G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a), not G. L. c. 209C, § 20….”}
